items.item_details:
The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-270-6402. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

items.item_details:
Pursuant to Title V Section 58301 the Board of Trustees shall hold a public hearing on the proposed budget on or before the 15th day of September.  
	 
The District is required to make available the proposed budget for public inspection at least three days prior.  Notification of date and location on the proposed budget shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the District.  Accordingly, notice was posted in the San Jose Mercury News on Saturday, August 24, 2013, and the proposed budget was made available to the public for inspection Friday, September 6, 2013.
	 
This item is intended to identify the place on the agenda where the public may appear and object to the proposed budget or any item in the budget.

items.item_details:
The District employs non-bargaining unit employees in various categories to support programs and services.  These categories are: short-term assignments with limitations as defined in the CSEA/District collective bargaining agreement; substitutes to fill positions for employees on leave of absence or in vacant positions; professional experts with specialized knowledge or expertise not generally required of, or found within, the employee classifications established by the Governing Board; and athletic support staff for athletic activities.
	 
.
Professional Expert Position Establishment
The establishment of the following position at District Office effective 08/20/13: 
	 
Writer/Reporter, Human Resources

items.item_details:
Education Code 81655 stipulates that no contract is an enforceable obligation of the District until it has been approved by the Board of Trustees. Board Policy 6100 establishes the authority of certain administrators to approve contracts under the bid limit prior to formal Board approval. All contracts and purchase orders exceeding the current bid limit of $83,400 shall have prior Board approval as a separate board item.
	 
This consent item presents for Board approval: all purchase orders for this period, which includes purchase orders for administratively approved contracts exceeding $1,000, as well as additional contracts that, although are not executed by way of purchase order, are deemed appropriate to be added by the Purchasing Department.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees ratify the contracts and purchase orders for the period of July 10, 2013 through August 9, 2013 as noted in the attached documents.
items.item_text: Ratification of Contracts and Purchase Orders
items.item_text_raw: 6. Ratification of Contracts and Purchase Orders

items.item_details:
Per California Public Contract Code Section 20652, “the governing board of any community college district without advertising for bids, and when the board has determined it to be in the best interest of the district, may authorize by contract, lease, requisition, or purchase order … [to] purchase materials, supplies, equipment … and other personal property for the district in the manner in which the public corporation or agency is authorized by law to make the lease or purchase.” The contract must be based on the same prices and upon the same terms and conditions of a negotiated contract between the supplier and another public corporation or agency.
	 
Authorization to award the contract without advertising for bids by determining it is in the best interest of the District to ‘piggyback’ on an already competitively-bid contract between National Joint Powers Alliance (NJPA) and Steelcase, Inc. NJPA is a Municipal Contracting government agency established through legal statute in 1978, serving over 30,000 members throughout the nation with competitively awarded purchasing solutions from industry-leading vendors. This ‘piggyback’ option will be with One Work Place L. Ferrari, an authorized dealer of Steelcase, Inc. 
	 
Attached are an affidavit of publication, a contract award with NJPA and Steelcase, Inc., and a letter from Steelcase, Inc. certifying that One Work Place L. Ferrari is an authorized dealer.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees authorize the District to 'piggyback' on the National Joint Powers Alliance (NJPA) contract with Steelcase, Inc. through One Work Place L. Ferrari (an authorized dealer).
items.item_text: Piggyback Steelcase, Inc. Contract Through One Work Place L Ferrari (Authorized Dealer)
items.item_text_raw: 7. Piggyback Steelcase, Inc. Contract Through One Work Place L Ferrari (Authorized Dealer)

items.item_details:
Since 2000, the Workforce Institute has contracted with the City of San Jose (work2future) to provide job readiness workshops to Santa Clara County job seekers at the Campbell, Gilroy, and San Jose One Stops. Workshops provided to job seekers help equip them with the skills they need to market themselves in this and future competitive job markets.
	 
For program year 2013-2014, work2future has awarded a NTE contract pool of $2,091,767 to its service providers. The overall contract dollars will be allocated to the various providers of instructor led workshops and online training as needed. Actual revenue earned through the WIA Overall Occupational Skills Training Pool is predicated on clients choosing Workforce Institute courses from a menu of workshops offered via the multiple providers. Based on workshops provided in 2012-13 Workforce Institute anticipates realizing $250,000 of this pool in 2013-14.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the 2013-2014 WIA Overall Occupational Skills Training Pool Contract

items.item_details:
On June 28, 2011, the Board of Trustees conducted a Special Study Session designed to focus on the "Six Shared Accreditation Findings" issued by the Accrediting Commission for which there was districtwide or trustee responsibility.  Four of the six shared recommendations specifically focused on board governance concerns. Following the presentation, then Board President Ron Lind committed the board to the identification of specific actions needed to address and remedy the Commission findings. He went further indicating that a specific workplan, dates and targets for corrective actions would be developed and implemented. As promised, since that time, the Board of Trustees has developed a workplan, prioritized activities, conducted a 360 Board Evaluation process and on February 12, 2013, formally established an ongoing  Board Training and Development Schedule.  One of the training topics was identified as  "Board Governance: Training and Exploration of the Carver Policy Governance Model."
	 
On Saturday, August 24, 2013, the Board of Trustees held a Special Governing Board Meeting in which they received training on the Carver Policy Governance Model. The training was provided by Miriam Carver, Carver Consulting. Ms. Carver provided an overview of the principles of board governance and leadership, differentiation between the roles of the college board and the chief executive officer, the board's accountability to their "constituents, " (defined as the  840,000  voters in the seven trustee district service areas,)  evaluation of the chief executive officer and the board itself, how to maintain board discipline, differentiation between policy and management, and many other such relevant topics.
After the training, the board discussed its desire to use the Carver Policy Governance Model as its approach for providing governance and leadership for the district and the need to declare their intent at their next meeting; including a discussion of the preparatory steps leading to the adoption of the model.
	 
Proposed Next Steps in the Process
	 
In Preparation for the adoption of a different policy/governance model is necessary for the board to implement a series of steps as folfollows:
	 
Introduce principles, concepts and guidelines to district leadership; namely, the board’s internal constituency groups, and to the external community.
Introduce the concept during Professional Development Day 8/29/13
Chancellor to place on the District Council Agenda on 9/16/13, review concept and provide resources to constituents for dissemination.   Discuss main rationale and concept
Discuss proposed timeline for implementation
Seek commitment from those present about their responsibility to disseminate the information
Board should ensure its clear understanding of policy development by setting up training in the following areas:
Governance Process
Board Management
Board Delegation
Executive Limitations
Clearly understand and establish a monitoring process for the work that is delegated to the Chancellor
Clearly understand and differentiate between “Ends” and “Means” Policies
Conduct a “Legal Check-up” to ensure that processes and procedures are in compliance with existing law.
Establish a “Roll-out”  or effective date
Plan the Agenda for the coming year.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees initiate a process to adopt the Carver Policy Governance Model.
items.item_text: SJECCD Board of Trustees: Process for the Implementation of a Different Governance and Policy Model
items.item_text_raw: 1. SJECCD Board of Trustees: Process for the Implementation of a Different Governance and Policy Model

items.item_details:
ADOPTION OF THE FISCAL YEAR 2013/2014 BUDGET
	 
The San Jose/Evergreen Community College District proposed Adopted Budget for Fiscal Year 2013/2014 is included as part of this item.  The California Community Colleges Chancellor's Office requires the District's Board of Trustees to approve the adopted budget by September 15, 2013.  The District Budget Committee has reviewed this budget and the underlying budget assumptions.  
	 
The Adopted Budget is provided as an attachment to this item and also can be accessed on the District's web site at http://www.sjeccd.edu/business/AdminServices/Pages/BudgetReports.aspx.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees adopt the Fiscal Year 2013/2014 budget as presented.

items.item_details:
Starting in 2010 the District purchased several new pieces of service equipment for the EVC Grounds Department.  The equipment is parked at the District Warehouse area without a covered structure to protect them from the elements.  
	 
The EVC District Warehouse Carport Project is intended to provide two carport structures for the equipment and a safe working environment for the Grounds personnel to properly service the equipment.
	 
The Board has previously approved Artik Art & Architecture to provide design services for the project.  On August 28, 2013 construction bids were received on that design.  The project was posted on the Districtâs purchasing website, advertised in local papers on August 6th, August 13th and published at 20 local buildersâ exchanges and plan rooms.  In addition, invitations to bid were sent to over 120 contractors including small, minority and woman-owned firms.  Bids were received as follows: 
	 
Integra Construction               $218,500
CALSTATE                            $228,000
ADA Construction                 $248,777
Rodan Builders                       $270,000
Paris Construction                   $363,880
	 
Integra Construction from Pleasanton, CA is determined to be the lowest responsible bidder in the amount of $218,500.  However, the construction estimate for the project was $150,000.  For this reason it is recommended that the District accept the following two Alternate Bid prices as submitted by Integra Construction:
	 
Deduct Air Compressor          $
Deduct Carport B                   $
	 
Therefore it is recommended to award a contract to Integra Construction in the amount of $144,947 for the remaining scope of work.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve issuance of a construction contract to Integra Construction in the amount of $144,947 for the EVC District Warehouse Carport Project.
items.item_text: Measure G-2004 Bond Program: EVC District Warehouse Carport Project
items.item_text_raw: 5. Measure G-2004 Bond Program: EVC District Warehouse Carport Project

items.item_details:
On May 14, 2013 the Board approved the use of the Design-Build delivery method for the construction of facilities and associated improvements, constituting the North District Multi-Disciplinary Building project ("Joint Use Facility") within the Milpitas Unified School District as part of the G2004 bond.
	 
The California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA) requires that an environmental review of the project site be conducted.  As such, the District will utilize an Environmental consulting firm to develop an environmental impact report (EIR) and associated mitigation monitoring program services for the proposed Milpitas site to support the successful implementation of the construction project as identified in the Joint-Use 21st Century Post-Secondary Educational Center program.
	 
The District issued a request for qualifications from environmental consultants and received proposals from three firms.  The selection committee consisted of representatives from both districts.  The respondents’ Statement of Qualifications was reviewed against the requirements set forth in the Request for Qualifications (RFQ) and ranked according to a point value assigned to each of four categories.  The committee selected Impact Sciences, Inc. who achieved the highest ranking of 93 points, representing the best overall value of qualifications, experience, scope of work, fee and proposal presentation.
	 
The contract value is $119,490

items.item_details:
As part of the effort to improve the EVC Central Plant and expand the Police Station, it was necessary to relocate temporarily the Police Station.  Construction of this temporary station was done through the Interim Police Facility and Measure G-2010 Offices Project.  
	 
In November 2012, the Board approved the Construction Agreement for BHM Construction, Inc. to perform the Work.  In December 2012, construction operations began and in April 2013, major construction operations were completed.  As of September 1, 2013 all construction work has been approved by Architect of Record, all closeout documents have been received, Change Orders have been approved and all contracts have been closed.  The Board is asked to approve the Notice of Completion for the Interim Police Facility & Measure G-2010 Offices Project.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the Notice of Completion for the Evergreen Valley College Interim Police Facility & G2010 Offices Project.

items.item_details:
In March of 2013 the District engaged Simpson Gumpertz and Heger, Inc. to provide design services to replace the roof of the Jaguar Gym at San Jose City College.  In April of 2013 an ICA was executed between Simpson Gumpertz and Heger, Inc. and the San Jose Evergreen Community College District for $80,750.  During design it became apparent that additional services would be required in the roof replacement due to a change in scope of the soffit edge detail.  Additional services included submittal review for details provided by Waterproofing Associates as a substitute for the original design and site time for reviewing the installation of the revised design details. This revision provides for the additional services required to design and administer the necessary design changes.
	 
Original Agreement - $80,750
Revision No. 1 - $20,000
Revision No. 2 - $5,055
Revised contract value - $105,805
items.item_recommendation: The Board is asked to approve ICA revision No. 02 in the amount of $5,055 to SIMPSON GUMPERTZ & HEGER, INC. for additional design services for the Jaguar Gym Roof Replacement Project.
items.item_text: Measure G-2010 Bond Program: Jaguar Gym Roof Replacement
items.item_text_raw: 8. Measure G-2010 Bond Program: Jaguar Gym Roof Replacement

On November 14, 2012 the board approved a Contract in the amount of $338,100 which consisted of painting all interior walls and stair wells of the Technology Center, repair and replacement of ceiling panels and damaged walls as needed.  Painting of all exterior surfaces and doors, excluding brick, replacing joint sealant of the General Education Building at San Jose City College. 
	 
Change Order No. 001 includes remaining unused allowances from the contract.  This change was negotiated for a deductive cost of ($35,828) for a revised contract value of $302,272.  This final Change Order represents a total Change Order percentage of negative 11% against the original contract.

items.item_details:
A year ago Evergreen Valley College began a campus-wide landscape assessment, planning and programming effort.  The intent was to perform a rigorous physical assessment of the site to fully understand the problems the campus faces. The design firm of Meyer+Silberberg (M+S) was selected through a competitive process to perform this work.  Their assessment included a review of the following elements: accessibility, paving condition and traffic flow, tree/plant/soil health, irrigation, exterior wayfinding and exterior lighting. This documentation provided detailed data into the issues the campus faces and steered prioritization by the College of improvements to be addressed. The final step was a conceptual design to support a long term plan for the campus landscape that is accessible, welcoming, and sustainable, with the goal of creating beautiful outdoor spaces for study and socializing.  
	 
A number of projects resulted from the assessment made at EVC.  One of the College’s priority projects is to make improvements to the general landscape (grounds and trees), its irrigation systems, and to address non-compliant ADA access.  (This project has a construction value of approximately $1 million.)  While it is normal to take competitive proposals for individual project RFQ’s, the work of this scope is very complex and dependent on detailed knowledge of the existing conditions at EVC.  Meyer + Silberberg, by virtue of having done the initial assessment, has that detailed knowledge.  Other firms that would be asked to propose would require additional staff time to review the assessment report and investigate the existing conditions, causing their costs to be higher and affecting the speed of project delivery.  For this reason, M+S was asked to submit a total-cost proposal for design services.  The initial proposal received was $175,000.  In thoroughly evaluating the scope and pricing, and in negotiation with M+S, a concise and appropriate scope of work was established at a reasonable cost for the design effort of $142,300.  As the scope will require numerous tasks that will tie into existing conditions, this reduction in fee allowed the College to include an allowance for unanticipated conditions of $40,000 should be included.  (This allowance is only used at the direction of the District.)
	 
In total, the recommendation is to award a PAA for Design and Construction Phase Services as an extension of Meyer + Silberberg’s initial services for $182,300.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Project Assignment Amendment EVC-02 with Meyer + Silberberg Land Architects in the amount of $182,300 for design services related to Landscape Irrigation, Tree Maintenance and ADA Paving Upgrades at Evergreen Valley College.
items.item_text: Measure G-2010 Bond Program: Project Assignment Amendment (PAA) EVC-02 Meyer + Silberberg Land Architects for Landscape Irrigation, Tree Maintenance and ADA Paving Upgrades design services.
items.item_text_raw: 10. Measure G-2010 Bond Program: Project Assignment Amendment (PAA) EVC-02 Meyer + Silberberg Land Architects for Landscape Irrigation, Tree Maintenance and ADA Paving Upgrades design services.

items.item_details:
The updated 2025 Facility Master Plan for Evergreen Valley College includes the relocation of the automotive technology program to a new Automotive Technology building at the northwest section of the campus.  In order to construct the building in this location it is necessary to extend utility services to the project site.
	 
The Board has previously approved Salas O’Brien to provide design services for this work.  Construction bids were taken on that design on August 28, 2013.  The project was posted on the District’s purchasing website, advertised in local papers on August 6th, August 13th and published at 20 local builders’ exchanges and plan rooms.  In addition, invitations to bid were sent to over 100 contractors including small, minority and woman-owned firms.  Bids were received as follows:
	 
Rodan Builders Inc.                $699,000
Blocka                                     $718,000
JKL                                         $749,600
Gonzales & Stronck                $774,000
KMS                                       $778,842
Swenson & Associates            $832,000
RC Benson                              $854,000
ESI                                          $985,000
	 
Rodan Builders Inc. from Burlingame, CA is determined to be the lowest responsible bidder.  The construction estimate for the project was $700,000.  
	 
It is recommended that Rodan Builders Inc. be awarded a contract in the amount of $699,000 for the project noted above based on the evaluation of the received bids and required documentation.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the award of a construction contract to Rodan Builders Inc. in the amount of $699,000 for the EVC Auto Technology Building Utilities Extension & Upgrade Project.
items.item_text: Measure G-2010 Bond Program: EVC Auto Technology Building Utilities Extension & Upgrade Project
items.item_text_raw: 11. Measure G-2010 Bond Program: EVC Auto Technology Building Utilities Extension & Upgrade Project

items.item_details:
In March, 2013 the District issued a Request for Qualifications (RFQ) for Technology Consulting Services to perform design professional services related to 1) infrastructure assessment/recommendations for upgrades for District and College infrastructure, 2) network planning, 3) development of District design standards for cabling and networking and 4) relocation of the EVC MDF and the ITSS server farm.  Outreach efforts included posting to the District Purchasing website and direct contact by e-mail and phone to minority and woman-owned small disadvantaged businesses.
	 
On April 9, 2013, the District received a Statement of Qualifications (SOQ) from six (6) firms in response to the RFQ.  A Review Panel consisting of representatives from the District, College and CampusWorks reviewed each SOQ.  The Panel evaluated each SOQ received, discussed the relative strengths of each firm and ranked the responses.  From those rankings, the Review Panel selected three (3) firms to be invited for presentation/interview (in alphabetical order):
	 
Salas OâBrien
Shen Milsom Wilke
TMAD Taylor and Gaines
	 
The interviews were held on May 17, 2013.  Based on the compilation of SOQ and interview results, the interview panel selected and recommends TMAD Taylor and Gaines (TTG) as the Design Professional for Technology Consulting Services as defined in the RFQ.
	 
Negotiations have resulted in the recommended Project Assignment Amendment in the amount of $210,000 for the assessment and design programming portion of the overall project.  Subsequent to this effort there will be specific design projects to encompass the full scope of the RFQ.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve issuance of Project Assignment Amendment EVC-01in the amount of $210,000 to TMAD Taylor and Gaines as Design Professional for Technology Consulting Services (assessment and design programming phase).
items.item_text: Measure G-2010 Bond Program: Technology Design Consultant Award
items.item_text_raw: 12. Measure G-2010 Bond Program: Technology Design Consultant Award

items.item_details:
On July 9, 2013 the Board agreed to enter into a contract with Preston Pipelines, Inc. to provide construction services to repair and replace aged water mains on the San Jose City College campus. 
	 
Construction contracts often times experience unforeseen conditions, coordination gaps and/or design changes that require an adjustment to the contract price and/or duration in the form of a Change Order.  Preston Pipelines submitted written pricing proposals for changes detailed in the attachment inclusive of additional or deleted labor, materials, equipment, and time with the applicable prescribed mark-ups.  The proposals have been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.
	 
The three items in this change order total and add to the contract an amount of $12,566 and 4 additional days to the contract duration to perform the necessary additional work. The total percentage of change orders against the original contract amount, including this change, is 6.25%.
	 
Original Contract Amount                $201,000
Previous Approved Changes                      $0
Change Order No. 001                      $12,566
Total Contract and Changes            $213,566
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Change Order No. 001 for Preston Pipelines, Inc. in the amount of $12,566 for the San Jose City College Water System Repairs Project.
items.item_text: Measure G-2010 Bond Program: SJCC- Water System Repairs Project #G2010.0053, Project #31308 Change Order No. 001
items.item_text_raw: 13. Measure G-2010 Bond Program: SJCC- Water System Repairs Project #G2010.0053, Project #31308 Change Order No. 001

items.item_details:
San Jose City College wishes to establish an agreement to continue to partner with St. Elizabeth's Day Home, a California nonprofit charitable public benefit corporation (hereafter "Sub-Contractor"). San Jose City College has found the Sub-Contractor able to meet the needs of the Child Development Division, California Department of Education (CDC) for state child development program services for both Toddler and Preschool Care. 
	 
As the certified CDC contractor, SJCC will continue to conduct fiscal agent responsibilities and compliance checks to meet the conditions of its contract with the California Department of Education, Child Development Division and to adhere to the Funding and Conditions (FT&C).
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the Independent Contractor Agreement and Agreement for Child Development Services with St. Elizabeth's Day Home for the 2013-2014 fiscal year in the amount of $274,952.64.

items.item_details: At the August 13, 2013, Board Meeting, The Colleague ERP Conversion Approach Document was shared with the board as an information item with the understanding that a more detailed action item would follow on the September 10 agenda.  The work of providing three options is completed, but the district is in the process of determining the best selection for this project. However, there are certain aspects of the Colleague ERP Conversion Project that are sole source items from Ellucian.  We are requesting that the Board approve the Ellucian contract for these items to secure the discounts on SQL Port, CROA, and the mobile license fees as they expire on September 30, 2013 (roughly a $150,000 savings).  The total cost for these items is not to exceed $700,000.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve an Ellucian sole source addendum to existing contract for software required for the ERP Conversion Project in an amount not to exceed $700,000.

items.item_details: The Board and Chancellor are agendized to meet in closed session regarding the employment of the Vice Chancellors and EVC President.  In the event that the Board's and Chancellor's discussion addresses anything related to terms of the contract, action to modify the contract must occur in open session.  This Action Item is placed on the Agenda to give the Board the ability to modify the terms of the contract consistent with the finalization of the evaluation process.

items.item_details:
Presently the president and vice chancellor positions are designated as M-35 on the management salary schedule.
	 
In order to make a distinction between the executive management positions and those management positions identified as MSCC positions, a separate salary schedule and designation is being proposed.
	 
In the proposed salary schedule the range designation is to be EM-1 and the steps are to mirror the current steps approved by the Board for the EVC President.
	 
This action shall provide the establishment of a salary schedule effective for July 1, 2014. It will be relied upon for the recruitment of the SJCC President and the future Vice Chancellor, Technology. 
	 
	 
EM-1 $188,221 $197,632, $207,513, $217,889
	 
EM-1 President
EM-1 Vice Chancellor
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees adopt a salary schedule for Executive Management to be effective July 1, 2014.

items.item_details: The Accrediting Commission for Community and Junior Colleges requested Evergreen Valley College complete a Midterm Report with the requirement that the report be reviewed and approved by the Board of Trustees prior to its submission date of October 15, 2013. A midterm report is prepared in the third year after each comprehensive institutional self-study report. This is the 1st reading of the draft Accreditation Midterm Report.
items.item_text: EVC Accreditation Midterm Report - First Reading
items.item_text_raw: 3. EVC Accreditation Midterm Report - First Reading

items.item_details: The Accrediting Commission for Community and Junior Colleges (ACCJC) reviewed the San Jose City College (SJCC) Institutional Self Study Report at its meeting on January 11-13, 2011, and the report of the evaluation teams that visited the college in October 2010 . The Commission acted to issue Probation and asked the college to address every recommendation, correct the deficiencies, and resolve the issues identified in the Commission's letter of January 31, 2011. The college submitted follow-up reports to the ACCJC in October 2011 and October 2012 and was removed from probation and reaffirmed accreditation in January 2013. The attached Midterm Report is being presented to the Board for a first reading and will be submitted for approval at the October 8, 2013, Governing Board Meeting. Interim President Byron Breland will provide an overview of the college's report.
items.item_text: SJCC Accreditation Midterm Report-First Reading
items.item_text_raw: 4. SJCC Accreditation Midterm Report-First Reading

items.item_details:
The development of a "District Climate of Civility, Mutual Respect and Professionalism,"  was one of the 2012-2013 Performance Objectives established for the Chancellor by the Board of Trustees. In response the Chancellor prioritized the development of a statement on civility that would serve a dual purpose (1) respond to the board’s request; and, (2) comply with Accreditation Standard II.A.3.C which states that institutions of higher education must ensure the 
	 
“Recognition of what it means to be an ethical human being and effective citizen:  qualities include an appreciation of ethical principles, civility and cultural interpersonal skills; respect for cultural diversity; historical and aesthetic sensitivity; and the willingness to assume civic, political, and social responsibilities locally, nationally and globally (Standard II.A.3.C.)”
	 
 A workplan was developed including some of the following key developmental and awareness activities: 
	 
Formation of the Civility Task Force – a districtwide invitation to serve was sent out and a significant number of individuals agreed to serve.  District Council members were also invited to serve. The Civility Task Force met on 11.7.2012; 12.5.2012; 2.6.2013; 3.6.2013; 4.10.2013; 5.1.2013; and 8.7.2013.  Agenda and meeting notes can be viewed at the following link:  http://www.sjeccd.edu/aboutus/chancellor/Pages/Chancellor.aspx   
District Council consultation and review -   Drafts of the Civility Statement were shared and reviewed in several District Council meetings on:  12.20.2012; 2.21.2013; 3.21.2013; and 4.18.2013.
Professional Development Day (PDD) Presentations –presentations designed to increase awareness and describe the work of the Civility Task Force were made at both colleges on the following dates:
January 25, 2013 - conducted a PPT 
April 12, 2013 - including dissemination of draft statement
August 29, 2013 - including the beginning of an awareness campaign in conjunction with the college presidents including the dissemination wristlets imprinted with the words “Civility.Worth.Dignity," and the introduction of a slogan  or brand for the District as follows:  “Civility begins with me! Everyone has Worth and Dignity.”  
Attached is the final draft of the Civility Statement presented for first reading with expected action at the next meeting of the board scheduled for October 8, 2013.
items.item_text: Civility Statement (First Reading)
items.item_text_raw: 5. Civility Statement (First Reading)

items.item_details:
At the August 13, 2013, Board Meeting, the Colleague ERP Conversion Approach Document was shared with the Board as an information item.  Early estimates showed an investment of $5M to convert the new ERP solution rather than the $10M originally estimated for a total system replacement.  The total cost estimate has now been refined further by defining each vendor's role and associated investment, and the delivery options are presented in the attached power point presentation.  The presentation lays out three options for Board consideration. 
	 
The first option is to have Ellucian take the lead, serving as Project Manager for the Application Conversion and the Technical Project Lead for Conversion and SQL Migration.
The second option is to put all components out for bid.
The third option is to have CampusWorks take the lead, serving as Project Manager for the Application Conversion and Technical Project lead for Conversion and SQL Migration.
	 
Each option, detailing each vendor's role in the project and the resulting investment cost is provided in the attached power point presentation.
items.item_text: ERP Conversion Project
items.item_text_raw: 6. ERP Conversion Project

items.item_details:
This report represents the status of schedule and cost for Measure G-2010 projects from inception through August 31, 2013, with financial data reconciled through May 31, 2013.
	 
	 
#32107 (South Campus) – The schedule for this project has been put into “caution” due to ongoing efforts to align estimated project cost with allocated budget.  The entire project team (Gilbane, EVC, HMC and Blach) have been evaluating the design and scope of the project since the completion of Design Development to reconcile the estimated cost of the project and bring the project into budget.  It is expected that the final schedule impact will be determined by mid-September.
	 
#32111 (Automotive Technology) – The schedule for this project has been put into “caution” due to necessary effort to align estimated project cost with allocated budget.  The design team (Lionakis) informed the College at the completion of Design Development that the current estimated project cost is higher than budgeted.  An effort to reconcile the estimated cost of the design and bring the project into budget will be completed in September.
	 
#31121 (Photo Lab Relocation) - The contractor performing the work for the Photo Lab Relocation Project has failed several inspections over the last few weeks and will not complete the project on schedule before classes start on 9-3-13.  We are anticipating completion of the project approximately 3-4 weeks late, near the end of September.  We are working with College faculty and staff to ensure that students know where to go on the first day of class and to determine the best time for the program to move into the new space once it is complete.
	 
The three projects below cannot start and/or complete until the New Gym, a Measure G 2004 project, is complete.  Delays in the New Gym project have pushed to the point where it is now impacting the start and/or completion of the three projects below.
	 
#31110 Utility Extension for New & Existing Buildings
#31114 Aux Gym, Pool & Locker Room Demo
#31116 Campus Site Improvements
